title: West Indies skittle Pakistan for first away Test win against rivals since 1990
description: West Indies (win by 120 runs) 163 & 244; Pakistan 154 & 133 Jomel Warrican named player of match and seriesWest Indies secured their first Test win in Pakistan since 1990 after beating the hosts by 120 runs in the second match in Multan to ensure the series ended in a 1-1 draw.Pakistan needed 178 to win and sweep the two-match series after being reduced to 76 for four at stumps on the second day but lost two quick wickets when Saud Shakeel (13) and Kashif Ali (one) were removed cheaply by Kevin Sinclair and Jomel Warrican respectively. author: Reuters
excerpt: West Indies secured their first Test win in Pakistan since 1990 after beating the hosts by 120 runs on Monday to ensure the series ended in a 1-1 draw
text: West Indies secured their first Test win in Pakistan since 1990 after beating the hosts by 120 runs in the second match in Multan to ensure the series ended in a 1-1 draw.Pakistan needed 178 to win and sweep the two-match series after being reduced to 76 for four at stumps on the second day but lost two quick wickets when Saud Shakeel (13) and Kashif Ali (one) were removed cheaply by Kevin Sinclair and Jomel Warrican respectively.Mohammad Rizwan gave the hosts a fighting chance, scoring 25 runs off 62 deliveries, before the wicketkeeper-batter was sent packing in the 42nd over by Warrican, who did the bulk of the damage with the ball with five for 27 in the second innings.Reduced to 122 for eight, Pakistan’s chase fizzled out when Gudakesh Motie removed Noman Ali and Warrican bowled Sajid Khan.Asked for the formula to his success, which saw him take 19 wickets across the two matches, Warrican said: “Just the variation of pace and hitting the same length over and over. “Consistency is the key to everything I do.” The left-arm spinner was named player of both the match and the series. html:
West Indies secured their first Test win in Pakistan since 1990 after beating the hosts by 120 runs in the second match in Multan to ensure the series ended in a 1-1 draw.

Pakistan needed 178 to win and sweep the two-match series after being reduced to 76 for four at stumps on the second day but lost two quick wickets when Saud Shakeel (13) and Kashif Ali (one) were removed cheaply by Kevin Sinclair and Jomel Warrican respectively.

Mohammad Rizwan gave the hosts a fighting chance, scoring 25 runs off 62 deliveries, before the wicketkeeper-batter was sent packing in the 42nd over by Warrican, who did the bulk of the damage with the ball with five for 27 in the second innings.

Reduced to 122 for eight, Pakistan’s chase fizzled out when Gudakesh Motie removed Noman Ali and Warrican bowled Sajid Khan.

Asked for the formula to his success, which saw him take 19 wickets across the two matches, Warrican said: “Just the variation of pace and hitting the same length over and over. “Consistency is the key to everything I do.” The left-arm spinner was named player of both the match and the series. The hosts had won the first Test by 127 runs.

West Indies captain Kraigg Brathwaite said: “We haven’t played in Pakistan for a number of years, but we haven’t won here in a while, so to come here and do it as a young group is incredible.

“On this pitch, there’s a ball with your name on it around the corner. We did that with the bat in the second innings, and it was good to see. It was a good experience. When you get on better pitches, you can have a similar mindset and it will help you in the long run.”
